description: Largest difference between consecutive divisors of n (ordered by size).
comments: Equivalently, a(n) = n - n/p, where p = A020639(n) is the smallest prime divisor of n.Difference between n and its largest proper divisor. - _Omar E. Pol_, Aug 31 2011Is a(n) the least m > 0 such that n - m divides n! + m? - _Clark Kimberling_, Jul 28 2012Is a(n) the least m > 0 such that L(n-m) divides L(n+m), where L = A000032 (Lucas numbers)? - _Clark Kimberling_, Jul 30 2012Records give A006093. - _Omar E. Pol_, Oct 26 2013
links: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
A. Balog, P. Erd≈ës and G. Tenenbaum, On Arithmetic Functions Involving Consecutive Divisors, In: Analytical Number Theory, pp. 77-90, Birkhauser, Basel, 1990.
formula: a(n) = n - A032742(n). - _Omar E. Pol_, Aug 31 2011
example: For n = 35, divisors are {1, 5, 7, 35}; differences are {4, 2, 28}; a(35) = largest difference = 28 = 35 - 35/5.
mathematica: a[n_ ] := n - n/FactorInteger[n][[1, 1]]Array[Max[Differences[Divisors[#]]] &, 80, 2] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Oct 26 2013 *)
prog: (Haskell)a060681 n = div n p * (p - 1) where p = a020639 n-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Apr 06 2015(PARI) diff(v)=vector(#v-1,i,v[i+1]-v[i])a(n)=vecmax(diff(divisors(n))) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 02 2015(PARI) a(n) = if (n==1, 0, n - n/factor(n)[1,1]); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Oct 24 2015
author: _Labos Elemer_, Apr 19 2001
extensions: a(1)=0 added by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Oct 01 2015 at the suggestion of _Antti Karttunen_
